repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Ref: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/24252

- `crn` for rename
- `crr` for code actions
- `gr` for references
- `<C-S>` (in Insert mode) for signature help

`cr` is a generic "refactor" prefix (fits nicely with the mappings from [vim-abolish](https://github.com/tpope/vim-abolish/blob/master/doc/abolish.txt#L146)) too.

`crn` mnemonic: reName
`crr` is code actions for now, but can eventually be extended to provide a generic "menu" of refactor options

`gr` overrides a builtin mapping, but this is deemed acceptable since the default behavior is rarely useful. Users can delete the new default `gr` mapping if they don't want it.

comment_data.body:
Maybe creating a helper function here will make things tidier?

```suggestion
local map = function(mode, lhs, rhs, opts)
  if vim.fn.maparg(lhs, mode, false, false) == '' then return end
  opts.buffer = bufnr
  vim.keymap.set(mode, lhs, rhs, opts)
end
```

comment_data.body:
Not crazy about the double mapping, but we can revisit. We have a little time before this makes it to a release. If we did do the `<C-G>` prefix, I have a preference for `<C-G><C-S>` (mnemonic: "signature") since that can be typed with one hand (at least on QWERTY).

`<C-H>` might also be worth considering, though some people might use the default "backspace" behavior.

comment_regular_data.body: @folke @siduck @tjdevries (and everyone else that has an initial nvim configuration/distro, sorry you're a lot so I'm tagging the 1st that come to mind): You might want to reconsider your default keybinds to match these newly added ones.

After thinking about these some more I wonder if we should actually map commands like `gr` unconditionally, independent of a language server running and supporting the actions. 

With K, gq, and tagfunc mappings there are reasonable fallbacks sharing the semantics of the LSP versions, so a conditional mapping to enhance them makes sense. 

With `gr` you get entirely different behaviour if no server is running, which might be more confusing than getting an error stating that no language server is running or supports getting references.

No strong opinion on it, just wanted to bring it up

>  `crr` for rename. `cra` for code actions

`crn` is a nice mnemonic for "ReName". And that allows us to use `crr` for the general "code actions" entrypoint, which is analogous to the way that `dd`, `yy`, etc have traditionally been used as "convenience aliases".

>  `<C-S>` (in Insert mode) for signature help

would `ctrl-]` be worth claiming instead? somewhat analogous to normal-mode `ctrl-]`.

I have plans for `ctrl-s` in normal mode, to go to the "default [S]hell". But that doesn't necessarily conflict with this insert-mode purpose.

> would `ctrl-]` be worth claiming instead? somewhat analogous to normal-mode `ctrl-]`.

`C-]` already exists in insert mode to expand an abbreviation. I also use that as my expand snippet trigger (expanding a snippet is similar in spirit to expanding an abbreviation).

> > `crr` for rename. `cra` for code actions
> 
> `crn` is a nice mnemonic for "ReName". And that allows us to use `crr` for the general "code actions" entrypoint, which is analogous to the way that `dd`, `yy`, etc have traditionally been used as "convenience aliases".


So youre suggesting `crn` for rename and `crr` for code actions? That seems a lot more confusing than `r` for Rename and `a` for Action, but if it gets this out the door then sure.

> So youre suggesting `crn` for rename and `crr` for code actions? That seems a lot more confusing than `r` for Rename and `a` for Action,

My thinking is the "cr" prefix is for Refactoring-related things. `crr` can show a "code changes" menu even for non-LSP contexts (similar to `gO` which has different "backends"). So the LSP "actions" jargon shouldn't necessary drive this.

`crr` is also easier to type for this somewhat common use-case.

One more point comes to mind: The code action mappings should probably exist for both normal and visual mode.
E.g. in eclipse.jdt.ls there's support to select a range, and then use a "extract method" code action.

No strong opinion on the `crn`/`crr` discussion, but I'd prefer `crr` for rename and `cra` for code action.
(But I also use `<a-CR>` for code actions due to intellij habits, and have an additional `<leader>r` mapping for `vim.lsp.buf.code_action { context = { only = {'refactor'}}}`)

> After thinking about these some more I wonder if we should actually map commands like `gr` unconditionally, independent of a language server running and supporting the actions.
> 
> With K, gq, and tagfunc mappings there are reasonable fallbacks sharing the semantics of the LSP versions, so a conditional mapping to enhance them makes sense.
> 
> With `gr` you get entirely different behaviour if no server is running, which might be more confusing than getting an error stating that no language server is running or supports getting references.
> 
> No strong opinion on it, just wanted to bring it up

I think this makes sense and I did so in 25b7b1b06f69e3c42f05ac43f9f26c19bbf33786. Note that some of these mappings like `vim.lsp.buf.references()` and `vim.lsp.buf.code_action()` don't show any error or message of any kind if no LSP client is attached, but we can fix that later.

>My thinking is the "cr" prefix is for Refactoring-related things. crr can show a "code changes" menu even for non-LSP contexts (similar to gO which has different "backends"). So the LSP "actions" jargon shouldn't necessary drive this.

Agree on the `cr` prefix. For the "menu" concept tho, why not use `crO` and continue the `O` = "table of contents" paradigm?

>And that allows us to use crr for the general "code actions" entrypoint, which is analogous to the way that dd, yy, etc have traditionally been used as "convenience aliases".

`dd` and `yy` and `gcc` and `g??` etc. have the semantics of "operate on the current line". `crr` for rename doesn't follow this, but neither does `crr` for a menu. So I don't think `dd` and friends provide this precedent.

Although, looking at what [actual people use today](https://sourcegraph.com/search?q=context:global+lang:Lua+vim.lsp.buf.rename&patternType=keyword&sm=0), the `rn` mnemonic for "rename" is more common than I would have expected. So that's a point in `crn`'s favor.

> Agree on the `cr` prefix. For the "menu" concept tho, why not use `crO` and continue the `O` = "table of contents" paradigm?

"O" in `gO` means "outline", not "menu". And uppercase mappings are both hard to type and remember, so should be avoided, especially when we have a "family" that is prefixed with something like `cr`.

Is there any disagreement that `crr` is much easier to type? That is perhaps the strongest argument in favor of it. This mapping will be very commonly used, because it's the entrypoint for refactoring options.

`_defaults` has become a hodgepodge of mappinngs (vastly differing contexts) such as lsp, treesitter (gcc), quite a few autocmds, then we have others which enhance the defaults (gx). I think it is time to think about splitting this. And allowing an opt out of certain ones. The original content of this file, with things like `*` and `#` in visual mode, `gx`, and the terminal and other `autocmds` which generally added nice value, but this is getting a bit too opinionated. Not to mention the current mappings for lsp are set regardless of lsp client being attached.

> `_defaults` has become a hodgepodge of mappinngs (vastly differing contexts) such as lsp, treesitter (gcc), quite a few autocmds, then we have others which enhance the defaults (gx). I think it is time to think about splitting this.

That's an implementation detail , and solving it can happen after some thought. Doesn't need to be rushed.

> And allowing an opt out of certain ones.

Opting out of LSP mappings is described at `:h lsp-defaults-disable`.

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/47dbda97d2f40729733b1c0d1d13d914065af23c/runtime/lua/vim/lsp.lua#L318

oh, I see : 

> These are mapped unconditionally to avoid confusion

Ok. Do we need to update `:h lsp-defaults-disable` ?
